ygData.subject: Re: [neat] NIPS Paper on Transferring Deep Learning Features
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello Ken, Thanks! I’m pretty excited to have a NIPS paper. That’s been a conference publication venue on my career bucket list for a while. :0). As for

Subject: Re: [neat] NIPS Paper on Transferring Deep Learning Features
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=ZJpXxqQjyfjjYrrfs4E6Puz2sN5b2JeHsZnKlTIbM69nFzTVSWaB
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune
From: Jeff Clune <jclune@...>


--Apple-Mail=_4CE524C4-DE13-493F-9B1C-C3DC0EF9A106
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=utf-8

Hello Ken,

Thanks! I=E2=80=99m pretty excited to have a NIPS paper. That=
=E2=80=99s been a conference publication venue on my career bucket list for=
 a while. :0).  

As for your question, I hope the answer would become clea=
rer if you have time to read that section of the paper. It was too complica=
ted a result to summarize well in the half sentence we had in the abstract.=
 Sorry about that. 

Jason Yosinski, the first author on the paper, expands=
 on the meaning of that line below. His explanation makes sense to me, but =
I=E2=80=99ve been living with this paper for a while now. Please let me kno=
w if you have any more questions. 

Since Jason gives a more technical, mac=
hine-learning explanation below, I=E2=80=99ll provide a high-level summary =
that also heavily uses the metaphors I use to think about the result. Here =
goes:  if you train neurons together, while they are =E2=80=9Clearning toge=
ther=E2=80=9D they get themselves into a certain configuration that perform=
s well. But if you then remove one of the partners, leave the other parter =
trained/skilled, and try to have a new, randomly initiated (skill-less) neu=
ron try to start learning how best to interact with the skilled/trained par=
ter=E2=80=A6and you don=E2=80=99t allow the skilled partner to change too, =
then the untrained neuron and the skilled partner don=E2=80=99t perform wel=
l as a team. That=E2=80=99s what we mean by =E2=80=9Coptimization difficult=
ies due to splitting co-adapted neurons.=E2=80=9D We also found, though, th=
at if let both the novice neuron and the skilled partner co-evolve (i.e. yo=
u let the skilled partner learn how to interact with the novice), then this=
 problem goes away. In my metaphor, it suggests that you can=E2=80=99t pair=
 a newbie with an expert=E2=80=A6unless the expert also adapts to learn to =
interact with the idiosyncrasies of the newbie as the newbie learns. Why wo=
uld we ever want to freeze the expert and train a newbie: that happens any =
time you transfer feature layers in Deep Learning networks, but are worried=
 about overfitting on the new target dataset so you freeze the earlier laye=
rs to preserve the general features they have ported over from the original=
, larger, training set. 

=E2=80=94=E2=80=94=E2=80=94=E2=80=94=E2=80=94=E2=
=80=94=E2=80=94=E2=80=94=E2=80=94

Here is Jason=E2=80=99s take: 

The sent=
ence of the abstract could be expanded to something like the following:

Tr=
ansferability is negatively affected by two distinct issues: (1) the
specia=
lization of higher layer neurons to their original task at the
expense of p=
erformance on the target task, which was expected, and
also (2) optimizatio=
n difficulties encountered when chopping neural
nets in half, severing conn=
ections between neurons that had become
co-adapted in a particularly delica=
te way. As an example, if we cut a
trained network between layer 4 and 5 an=
d then try to relearn the 4 ->
5 weights while keeping the 3 -> 4 weights f=
ixed, it doesn't work as
well. This may indicate that the 3 -> 4 weights an=
d the 4 -> 5 weights
had converged together to a particularly good solution=
 that cannot be
re-found by training only the 4 -> 5 weights on their own f=
rom
scratch.

The mental picture I have of this is that when both 3 -> 4 we=
ights and
4 -> 5 weights are random, their individual objective function
la=
ndscapes are relatively wide basins. As either set of weights
changes, it c=
auses the other set of weights to have a more narrow
basin, but this is fin=
e, because they are both learning via gradient
descent together. As they se=
ek lower positions within their respective
basin, it is not disastrous that=
 their basin is becoming narrower.
But, at the point of convergence, if we =
re-randomize half the weights
and expect them to now find the previous narr=
ow basin from a distance,
it doesn't work as well. Of course, this is just =
one possible
explanation.

=E2=80=94=E2=80=94=E2=80=94=E2=80=94=E2=80=94

R=
egarding the author list: As you know, I did a postdoc with Hod. Jason is i=
n Hod=E2=80=99s lab, and has become a good friend and frequent collaborator=
. Yoshua Bengio became involved through Jason, who visited Yoshua=E2=80=99s=
 lab for a while last year to do research

Hope either of those explanation=
s answers your question. Thanks again for your interest in the paper. 


Be=
st regards,
Jeff Clune

Assistant Professor, Computer Science
Director, Evo=
lving Artificial Intelligence Lab <http://evolvingai.org/>
University of Wy=
oming
jeffclune@...
jeffclune.com

> On Nov 11, 2014, at 9:51 PM, ksta=
nley@... [neat] <neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
> 
> Hi Jeff,
> 
> =
Congrats on getting a paper into NIPS, that's a great accomplishment!   The=
 paper also looks very interesting in relevant, though I haven't had the ch=
ance yet to read through it in detail.  But I wonder if you could elaborate=
 on one of the points from the abstract that sounds really interesting for =
those who might like an extended preview :)  In particular:
> 
> "(2) optim=
ization difficulties related to splitting networks between co-adapted neuro=
ns, which was not expected"
> 
> I don't understand exactly what that means=
, but it sounds very interesting.  What is the main  lesson of that point?
=
> 
> By the way, how did you end up with such an unusual team of authors, i=
ncluding Bengio?  
> 
> Best,
> 
> ken
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_4CE524C4-DE13-493F-9B1C-C3DC0EF9A106
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/html;
	charset=utf-8
